Award.AwardTitle: Establishment and stabilization of head-to-tail polarity in mosquitoes
Award.AbstractNarration: Establishing the primary body axis is fundamental to animal development. This research project builds on the discovery of a novel gene, termed panish, that establishes head to tail polarity and anterior body plan of a mosquito-related midge, Chironomus riparius. Prior to this work, the only factor known to fulfill this role in insects was the homeobox gene bicoid, discovered in Drosophila nearly 30 years ago. Bicoid is now firmly established as a fundamental model for molecular gradients and embryo patterning. Surprisingly, most insects lack bicoid and a major question in the field is how other insects establish head-to-tail polarity during embryonic development. Preliminary phylogenetic and genomic studies indicate that global body plan organizers such as bicoid and panish evolved independently multiple--perhaps even many times within the group of flies. The proposed research will test this hypothesis using high-throughput sequencing technology and will characterize experimentally the molecular nature of the panish gene product. The expected results will help to understand a fundamental mechanism of animal development in its evolutionary context. The project also provides training opportunities and is tied to a joint research project with a local high school that was initiated in 2011. In this collaboration ninth and tenth graders, under the supervision of two collaborating high school teachers with entomological expertise, seek to develop culture techniques for a specific fly species that may provide important information on the evolution of primary embryonic axis determinants in flies. The collaborating high school teachers incorporated the project into their curriculum to teach scientific methodology. Additional science-education outreach tied to this project specifically targets underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
a)  Intellectual Merit

Research supported by this award has shown that different species of flies (Diptera) have evolved structurally unrelated “anterior axis determinants”, even though their embryos are morphologically similar.  Anterior determinants are primarily defined by their loss-of-function phenotype: headless embryos with two mirror-image tail-ends. A transcriptome-profiling approach was developed to identify anterior and posterior localized maternal transcripts in freshly deposited eggs of six biting and non-biting midge species and a soldier fly species, providing a phylogenetic framework for the evolution of primary axis determinants in dipteran embryos. Gene knockdown experiments in two of these species, Chironomus riparius (a representative of the culicomorphan mosquitoes) and Clogmia albipunctata (a close relative of sand flies), showed that this approach correctly predicted their anterior determinants.

In Chironomus, the anterior determinant is encoded by a newly evolved cysteine-clamp gene, named panish. The first two exons of panish are shared with a nucleosid kinase gene while the portion encoding its DNA-binding cysteine-clamp domain exhibits homology to pangolin/tcf, the effector gene of canonical Wnt signaling. Homologs of panish were only found in a subgroup of chironomids, indicating a recent evolutionary origin of this gene. This result demonstrated for the first time that flies use structurally unrelated genes to specify the anterior body plan and head-to-tail polarity.

In Clogmia, the function of anterior axis determinant has been adopted by a  maternally expressed transcript variant of the conserved segmentation gene odd-paired, named Cal-opaMat. Knockdown of Cal-opaMat resulted in embryos with tail-to-tail polarity (as panish knockdown).  Conversely, ectopic expression of Cal-opaMat at the posterior pole resulted in head-to-head polarity. This gain-of-function assay was then used to show that timing and localization of odd-paired activity rather than Cal-Opa specific protein sequence is key for its function as anterior determinant in Cogmia. Importantly, even Drosophila mRNA of odd-paired were found to induce head development in Clogmia when provided in freshly deposited eggs. These findings demonstrate that a single gene can evolve an entirely new gene function via alternative transcription without protein evolution.

Given that alternative transcription, i.e., the use of alternative promoters and polyadenylation signals, is a very common phenomenon - it also applies to the vast majority of human genes - the results of this award suggest that alternative transcription plays an important role in the evolution of gene regulatory networks and deserves much more attention in evolutionary developmental biology.

b)  Broader Impacts

The award supported two postdoctoral scholars and two graduate students, and helped to create training opportunities for rotating graduate and undergraduate students (3), NSF-supported visiting EDEN fellows (2), and summer interns (6), including individuals from underrepresented minorities. Through student mentoring, teaching, and outreach the award contributed to the Early Identification Program (SR-EIP) from the Leadership Alliance at the University of Chicago, the NSF-funded EDEN program, the Research in the Biological Sciences (RIBS) program at the University of Chicago, the NSF-funded Insect Genetic Technologies Research Coordination Network (IGTRCN), the DNA Residency Program at the Field Museum of Natural History at Chicago, and high school outreach.
